titleEligibility: Who is eligible for VAT exemption in France?
contentEligibility-1: Persons residing outside the European Union for more than 6 months per year.
contentEligibility-1bis: The first criterion to benefit from the tax exemption is to reside outside the European Union. Since 1 January 2021, British residents can also benefit from tax relief.
contentEligibility-1ter: Be careful not to confuse European countries with EU countries. Here is a non-exhaustive list of European countries that do not belong to the European Union: Albania, Andorra, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Georgia, Iceland, Kosovo, Liechtenstein, Northern Macedonia, Moldova, Montenegro, Norway, United Kingdom, Russia, San Marino, Serbia, Switzerland, Turkey, Ukraine.
contentEligibility-1quater: It is important to note that although Monaco does not belong to the European Union, the principality cannot benefit from tax exemption in France. On the other hand, residents outside the European Union can benefit from tax exemption on Monegasque territory.
contentEligibility-1quinquies: In parallel, persons residing in certain third countries can benefit from the zero-rating of VAT. In particular, some of the overseas collectivities of the EU countries are called ‘third countries’.
contentEligibility-1sexies: The following French overseas collectivities can benefit from VAT refund: French Polynesia, New Caledonia, Wallis and Futuna, Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, the French Southern and Arctic Lands, etc.
contentEligibility-2bis: In addition to residing outside the European Union for more than 6 months a year, you must be 16 years of age or older to be eligible for a VAT refund.

contentTransparency-1: Understanding the mechanisms of tax exemption is not always easy. Between the amount incl VAT and the amount excl VAT, the refund rate, the service fees... it's easy to get lost and we understand you! Let's clarify all this together.
contentTransparency-2: First of all, it is important to remember that in France the amount of VAT is 20% of the purchase price excl VAT. This means that in reality the VAT represents 16.67% of the purchase price including VAT.
contentTransparency-3: For example, for 300€ of purchases in France, the amount of VAT will be 50€ (16.67% of 300€).
contentTransparency-4: There are also two ways of offering tax-free shopping for a French shop:
contentTransparency-li-1: Some retailers decide to manage their own tax-free operations (about 5% of shops in France).
contentTransparency-li-2: The vast majority of shops prefer to outsource this service to specialized companies called ‘tax-free operators’.
contentTransparency-5: What is the tax-free process for you?
contentTransparency-li-3: When you make a purchase in a shop that manages its own tax-free operations (let's remember that there are 5% on average on French soil), you will be able to recover the full VAT. However, you will need to be patient in the shop, as the seller will issue you with a tax-free paper form, and then, once the form has been validated, you will have to wait an average of 8 weeks to receive your refund. It is important to note that you cannot be reimbursed in cash and that you will need to provide one form per shop to validate your tax-free status with customs.
contentTransparency-li-4: When you make a purchase in a shop that subcontracts the tax-free operations, the rate of reimbursement generally observed is around 12% of the price of your purchase including VAT. If we take the example of the €300 purchase mentioned above, this means that you will receive a refund of €36. Again, you will have to queue in shop to get your paper form and then wait 10 weeks for your refund.
